items.title: War Rooms & Project Management: Concept to Execution
items.author: Mohith K Das
items.description:
“War Room!” sounds like an old WWII Era movie Right? Like in the old Indiana Jones movies where Nazis are planning an invasion and all of a sudden the protagonist sweeps in and beats the life out of the Nazi stooges, saves the haughty yet mesmerizing heroine and storms away?! Well, you wouldn’t be the First! and Kudos to you for having such a vibrant imagination!

“In War Truth is the First Casualty” — Aeschylus

The concept of War Room as such is borrowed from the military, It is a practice as old as time itself. From the point men figured out how to stack sticks, we’ve had wars, Our first projects!

Today we live in a world of abstraction, a world with a thousand challenges; wars unseen to the untrained eye; Our wars are subtle, we don’t spill a lot of Blood like our ancestors did! But the carnage none the less unsettling.

When it came to war things were simple for the early men, sticks and stones… Stab stab stab… Survive; With advancements in technology and intellect came strategy and complexity. Like in the time of the mighty Roman empire when the tales of skilled Generals were immortalized like those of Caesar and Hannibal.

Soon men could no longer manage these projects, Spanning over continents, Fought through many years and by Millions. Sheer brute force had now become a recipe for disaster.

Today as an Analyst and a spectator in the world of Information, I’ve had the honor of witnessing and help shape projects of my own. If you’ve ever managed a group of 10, workings on a Product you know the pain of having to manage client expectations, constant change requests, meeting deadlines and keeping up Team morale; Amongst a million other hiccups that may come up!

But towards the End of the Project, You’d probably have an intuitive feeling under your gut that some vague! yet crippling obstacle is gonna come up, Even if you’ve done everything right to the last letter! It may be due to Regression Bugs, Integrations Issues, Lack of Documentation or that new kid on your team who’d probably been briefed by their teammates rather than getting a proper K.T from you! This is where the concept of “War Room” comes up!

Though unusual and often only resorted to in on rare instances. Nothing I’d say meets its effectivity as a project management tool. Under normal circumstances, we plan a day before, on the scope and goals of the prescripted war room, The dependencies and time constraints.

Then we gather our core team members in the conference room. Decide on the resources required, project modules to work on, deliverables and get to work from Morning to Mid-night, albeit the days when you stay at the office in for work. Here we go through iterative Testing with intensive QA input. Each problem is dealt with within moments. The doubts are put on the table, brainstormed and solutions executed and tested on the spot. Unlike in long term planning, here we emphasize on getting our short terms objective done and aligned with our long term ones. It helps us breach the limitations of time and procedure and cuts straight to the chase.

Though helpful nothing beats the perks of following a well-set plan along the routes of agile. But none the less War Rooms are indeed a miracle of nature and should be credited no less. The 34th President of the US had a saying which goes by the lines of -

“In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispensable” — Dwight D. Eisenhower

One of the best planners of all time.

#ProjectManagement #WarRoom #ProductDevelopment #ProductEngineering #InformationTechnology #TeamWork #ProjectPlanning #ProductStrategy #BA

Published By

Mohith K Das
